section.title: Phrasal verbs
section.sectiontitle: A phrasal verb is verb + particle (preposition or adverb). Often the meaning is not related to the verb. Some phrasal verbs are intransitive; they have no object.
section.sectiontitle2: Some phrasal verbs are transitive and separable; the verb has an object, and the verb and particle can split. When the object is a pronoun (it, he, she, etc.), the verb and particle must split.

section.title: Phrasal verbs
section.sectiontitle: Some phrasal verbs are transitive (they have an object) and inseparable (the verb and particle don't separate).
section.text2a:
He got on it.
(NOT He it got on.)
section.sectiontitle2: Some verbs have two particles. These are transitive (they take an object) and inseparable (the verb and particle don't separate).
section.text3: I can't put up with this noise.
section.text3a: I can't put up with it.
section.text4: I get on with my brother.
